{% raw %}
{% endraw %}

part 1

{% raw %} 
class N(int):
    def __add__(self, x):
        return N(int(self) + x)
    def __sub__(self, x):
        return N(int(self) * x)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def convert(line):
    result = line
    result = result.replace("*", "-")
    for d in range(10):
        result = result.replace(str(d), f"N({d})")
    return result
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
convert("1 + 2 * 3 + 4 * 5 + 6")

'N(1) + N(2) - N(3) + N(4) - N(5) + N(6)'
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert eval(convert("1 + 2 * 3 + 4 * 5 + 6")) == 71
assert eval(convert("1 + (2 * 3) + (4 * (5 + 6))")) == 51
assert eval(convert("((2 + 4 * 9) * (6 + 9 * 8 + 6) + 6) + 2 + 4 * 2")) == 13632
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def read(f):
    return [line.rstrip() for line in open(f, 'r').readlines()]
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def p1(lines): return sum(eval(convert(line)) for line in lines)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
p1(read("./data/18.txt"))

5374004645253
{% endraw %}

part 2

{% raw %} 
class N(int):
    def __add__(self, x):
        return N(int(self) * x)
    def __mul__(self, x):
        return N(int(self) + x)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def convert2(line):
    result = line
    result = result.replace("*", "-")
    result = result.replace("+", "*")
    result = result.replace("-", "+")
    for d in range(10):
        result = result.replace(str(d), f"N({d})")
    return result
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
convert2("1 + 2 * 3 + 4 * 5 + 6")

'N(1) * N(2) + N(3) * N(4) + N(5) * N(6)'
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
assert eval(convert2("1 + 2 * 3 + 4 * 5 + 6")) == 231
assert eval(convert2("1 + (2 * 3) + (4 * (5 + 6))")) == 51
assert eval(convert2("((2 + 4 * 9) * (6 + 9 * 8 + 6) + 6) + 2 + 4 * 2")) == 23340
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
def p2(lines): return sum(eval(convert2(line)) for line in lines)
{% endraw %} {% raw %} 
p2(read("./data/18.txt"))

88782789402798
{% endraw %}

Appendix

There is an easier way to write a parser for part 2 (borrowing a trick from Knuth's FORTRAN 1 compiler):

#include <stdio.h>
#include <string.h>

int
main(int argc, char *argv[]) {
    printf("((");
    for (int i = 0; i < strlen(argv[1]); i++ ) {
        switch (argv[1][i]) {
            case '(': printf("(("); break;
            case ')': printf("))"); break;
            case '*': printf("))*(("); break;
            case '+': printf(")+("); break;
            default:  printf("%c", argv[1][i]); break;
        }
    }
    printf("))\n");
    return 0;
}

This program output can then be piped into bc.
